Daily Universal Register

Briefing

UK: The Scottish National Party launches its general election manifesto; the Social Democratic and Labour Party launches its manifesto; financial results from Nationwide Building Society and Severn Trent; Keep Britain Tidy reveals which English beaches have been awarded Blue Flag status and/or Seaside Awards.

Middle East: Donald Trump continues his first foreign trip as US president with a visit to Bethlehem, where he will meet Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president.

India: Financial results from Tata Motors, the owner of Jaguar and Land Rover.

US: President Trump’s final fiscal year 2018 budget proposal will be released.

On this day

In 1618 the second Defenestration of Prague took place, leading to the Thirty Years War; in 1785 Benjamin Franklin announced his invention of bifocals; in 1958 Mao Zedong started the “great leap forward” movement in China; in 1984 an explosion at a water treatment plant in Abbeystead, near Lancaster, killed 16 people; in 1998 the Good Friday Agreement was accepted in a referendum in Northern Ireland.

Nature notes

A small, jewel-like butterfly can now be looked for in many grassy places, from downland to wasteland. This is the small copper, which is golden-orange with black markings. The males hold territories, and will sit on a stone in them, looking out for passing females and chasing them. It will also fly up and drive off other males, and even other insects, its wings gleaming in the sunshine. It lays its eggs on sorrel. Another pugnacious butterfly that is now common in woods, and even in small wooded patches, is the speckled wood. It is a brown butterfly with creamy-white spots that look like dappled sunlight on its wings, resembling the leaves around it. The male of this species also holds a territory — if another male approaches, it flies at it and the two of them circle closely around each other. This encounter may last several minutes, with the two butterflies spiralling high into the air. The caterpillars feed on grass.

Derwent May

Birthdays today

Richard Ayoade, comedian and actor, The IT Crowd (2006-13), 40; Johnny Ball, actor and TV presenter, Play School (1964-88), 79; Rubens Barrichello, racing driver, Formula One (1993-2011), 45; Neil Black, performance director, UK Athletics, 58; Prof Alan Bowman, principal of Brasenose College, University of Oxford (2011-15), 73; Craig Brown, satirist, 60; Juliet Campbell, mistress of Girton College, University of Cambridge (1992-98), 82; Dame Joan Collins, actress, Dynasty (1981-89), The Stud (1978), 84; Marquess Conyngham, chairman, Slane Castle, 66; Very Rev John Drury, chaplain and fellow, All Souls College, University of Oxford, 81; Marvin Hagler, boxer, middleweight champion (1980-87), 63; Graeme Hick, England cricketer (1991-2001), 51; Richard Hill, rugby union player, England player (1997-2008), and England senior team manager, 44; Anatoly Karpov, chess player, world champion (1975-85), 66; David Kester, chief executive, Design Council (2003-12), 53; Sir John Lyons, linguist, master of Trinity Hall, Cambridge (1984-2000), 85; Lady Olga Maitland, Conservative MP (1992-97), 73; Bob Mortimer, comedian, 58; John Newcombe, tennis player, winner of seven Grand Slam singles titles and 17 doubles titles, 73; George Osborne, editor, Evening Standard, Conservative MP (2001-May 2017), chancellor of the exchequer (2010-16), 46; Peter Preston, editor, The Guardian (1975-95), 79; Heidi Range, singer-songwriter, former Sugababe, 34; Michel Roux Jr, chef patron, Le Gavroche, 57; Dame Janet Thornton, molecular biologist, director, European Bioinformatics Institute (2001-15), 68; Matt Wrack, general secretary, Fire Brigades Union, 55.
